Marvel took an idea full of promise and flushed it down the toilet, demonstrating their lack of understanding for their own comics.The second reason I truly hated this movie was the waste of casting for the movie. Nicholas Cage if given the right character can be very entertaining. HE WAS NOT. A glimpse of Eva Mendes can make almost any movie worth watching. NOT THIS ONE. I would hate the actors for even agreeing to make this movie, but right now I'm contemplating whether or not to sell my own soul to the devil in exchange for the destruction of MARVEL Studios. Lastly, what the hell was up with Blackheart? He was the lamest and least scariest villain I have or probably will ever see. He struck fear in no one, and his henchmen were less threatening than a hamster. Also, what was with the final showdown? I haven't been more disappointed since watching any scene from the movie Poseidon(2006).All in all, I feel not holding back on this movie serves true justice to this creation of momentous failures. I remember trying to get into the movie so hard that I fell asleep for 15 minutes from exhaustion. When I woke up, however, I felt better for myself because I know now that in a situation of extreme measures, I can sleep through it. Friday night, Feb. 16th has been stolen from me, and I will never forgive Ghost Rider for it.

I was surprised that my favourite comic book hero would be put out on the big screen as it is not one of the main comic icons like Superman, Batman, X-men, Spiderman, Hulk, Captain America, Fantastic 4, The Punisher, The Avengers, Iron Man... so I was excited. I enjoyed Daredevil but just couldn't bare Elektra so there would be a 50% chance Ghost Rider could be good or bad. I went in expecting the a sub-par comic-to-film movie but I was really entertained at how the writers put together the elements of the 2 Ghost Riders from the comic series (though I still would prefer they focus only the newer Rider :). The comics had 2 heroes Johnny Blaze (in 70's & 80's) & Dan Ketch (90's) btw, fyi Johnny Blaze is supposed to have reddish blonde hair. Anyhow the script did extremely well introducing the characters, their backgrounds & the concept of 'the rider'. Sam Elliot & Nic Cage did really well in carrying the flow of the movie as well immersing us into the films perception of the earth & hell realms. I can't say that much for Eva. Nic Cage has a great talent to really bring out the 'tormented good guy' hero characters like in his previous movies Matchstick Men, Weather Man, 8mm, Face Off, Con-Air, The Rock & It Could Happen to U.As a fan of the 90's comics, I wasn't all to happy about the films customizing of Ghost Rider elements but I guess it would be more appealing that way. The film, from the new millennium point of view, is an overall good 'comic-to-big screen' package . They really thought it out well laid a good foundation for the 'world of the Ghost Rider' in comparison to like say 'the world of Constantine'. Who is the Rider? What is the Rider? What does the Rider do? Who is Blackheart? Who is the Devil? Whats their relationship? I couldn't accept the movie version of the 'hell-cycle'though. Its too H.R. Geiger for my taste & that throws the concept off a little.For an additional treat for those of u who enjoyed the movie, try getting your hands on the Ghost Rider comics of the 90's like issues #1 - #50... u'll find many classic elements there like favourite phrases (when innocent blood is spilt.., in the presence of evil, I'm the Spirit of Vengeance), characters (like Johnny Blaze, Vengeance, The Punisher, Black Heart), famous moves (Chain fling, penance stare). Review title: Literally a Comic Book with a Flicker Rate and Sound.
Review_body: Ghost Rider had something none of the other, recent comic book movies had - the feeling that you were really watching a comic book. When you watch Spiderman, you can forget that this was once stationary drawings and just appreciate the movie. I didn't find that to be the case with Ghost Rider. The lines seemed like they were lifted right off the page, and while the actors all did good jobs with their delivery, there is a factor of just being silly (think R2D2 in Star Wars III: Revenge of the Sith). The action sequences are also a lot like a comic book - in that it's got dialog and specific actions placed with higher importance than good clean action. That having been said, it was fun to watch, it just wasn't breathtaking or spectacular in the slightest. Nicholas Cage was also the perfect person to play Ghost Rider, and he fits the part in both looks and attitude. Six out of ten for being watchable and enjoyable, but no immersion and a lot of mediocre qualities.

I understand it is a graphic novel and sometimes this is how they are written. I used to read comics and graphic novels until I lost interest in simple, childish, impractical writing. GR is intended for a younger than adolescent audience or at least seems this way. I also didn't like how some of the characters were introduced and scripted. As far as action goes, it was lacking. Action scenes were short,generic, and boring. It's funny that Nick Cage and the Hispanic chic actually agreed to act in Ghost Rider. If you want to see, see it, spend the money. Don't let any review persuade your decision. I would not recommend Ghost Rider to anyone. There are plenty of other movies worth one's price and time.

I'll say this right from the start: Ghost Rider is in no way, shape or form a great motion picture. Still, I enjoyed it. I find that sometimes movies call for different approaches. Sometimes you have to take them for what they are, and this can help enhance the viewing experience. Case in point, I was not expecting much from Ghost Rider. I could tell from the trailers that it wasn't exactly going to be a masterpiece, but still I was hoping to find some redeeming qualities and I did.As others have suggested, the acting is a bit iffy at best. Personally, I quite enjoyed Nicholas Cage as Johnny Blaze. He brings a sense of discovery to the role that works well. I also liked Peter Fonda as Mephistopheles. Yes, he's very understated and people have said that he seems bored, but honestly it worked for me because he comes off as a very cool customer and who's cooler than the devil himself? I'll also give props to Sam Elliott, who by this point is one of those actors who I think can do no wrong. It probably doesn't hurt that he basically plays the same character in every movie, but that's a moot point. On the other end of the spectrum, I was a bit disappointed with the casting of Wes Bentley. He just lacked any real menace. If it weren't for the CGI fangs they randomly added, I don't think there'd be much to fear at all. Likewise, Eva Mendes just seemed out of place. Don't get me wrong, she's a beautiful girl and her wardrobe throughout the film is certainly great (let's just say that her "girls" steal almost every scene she's in) but her acting chops aren't nearly as great as her cleavage.All this aside, I don't think most people go to a comic book movie hoping for Oscar-caliber performances. They go to have a good time, and in this regard I think Ghost Rider delivers. After all, it's a movie that rather prominently features a flaming biker skeleton riding a demon motorcycle. If that's not cool, I don't know what is.

from the trailer, i didn't expect much. the movie delivered as much. some nice scenes, but weak script.i guess it is hard to connect all the dots. ghost rider--devil's bounty hunter on a motorcycle--is an edgy (or rather over the edge) image. how do you give him purpose, make him a character with whom the audience can identify, make him likable, & keep him dark/edgy? i had no previous exposure to this marvel personality, but this film did not whet my appetite. i am not comic-book-clever enough to offer any constructive criticism, but this film missed the mark. i guess more depth (not vague soul-searching), intellect, & control over his power might help--maybe.

For a quick, light, good time, this will do just fine. Nic Cage works as Johnny Blaze ( I thought he'd look way too old, but he was believable). Sam Elliot was great as the Caretaker, Eva Mendes was good as Roxie, and everyone else was acceptable or better. The actual Ghost Rider effect was well done. This movie was better than Daredevil, not as good as any of the X-Men movies. Don't listen to the critics who trashed this film- they're allergic to fun. This won't win an Oscar, but hey, fun movies usually don't. I'll buy this on DVD.

Review title: A few glitches, but still one HELL of a RIDE!!
Review_body: Yes, there were a few goofs throughout (including the 360' jump billed as 300', a couple of minor continuity errors, etc) but Marvel has come shining through brilliantly yet again! Some of Ghost Rider's early lines were a bit cheesy (almost sub-neandertal), yes, but acceptable when you consider the context; early on, it was primal force of the The Ghost Rider in control rather than Johnny Blaze.Peter Fonda was another excellent choice, even if for no other reason than his numerous lead roles in biker films. In retrospect, Ghost Rider would have been a disappointment without the original 'Easy Rider'.I had one very demanding and slightly unusual expectation going into this movie: As a fan of both the Golden-Age and Silver-Age incarnations of The Ghost Rider, I was extremely critical of their handling of them both. Sam Elliot was nothing short of spectacular in his portrayal of the original (Golden-Age) Ghost Rider and the 'passing of the torch' scene (no pun intended) brought tears to my eyes.One minor disappointment was the absence of Stan Lee, who has habitually made cameo appearances in most of the recent Marvel movies. It's possible he was there and I missed him, but still...

Review title: Another horrible adaptation from the man behind Daredevil
Review_body: After watching Daredevil, I became a little weary of these comic book adaptations, as they seemed to swarm out one after the other onto the big screen. With Ghost Rider, a trés-cool anti-hero in the realm of Marvel comics, I admittedly had certain preconceived notions about how the movie would harmonize with its comic counterpart. However, this movie took no longer than 10 minutes to disappoint.As a movie, Ghost Rider fails to impress. What may have been lost in translation could have accelerated this blockbuster mess into a somewhat enjoyable movie. Many have warned not to expect Oscar-caliber performances from Cage, Mendes, and the other actors. However, the shallow characters cannot be overlooked. The acting overall was deplorable, and the actors themselves were too old. Nicolas Cage fails to make the connection between himself and his younger counterpart. The anger and passion with which the younger Johnny Blaze confronts his problems seems to fade away with age. Cage becomes a robot at best while Mendes shows off her breasts like they are the third and fourth actors on screen. Not to mention the "romance" between Cage and Mendes....well, it does not work in any way, remaining completely unbelievable after the first 5 minutes of the movie. The dialogue of the cowboy graveyard caretaker is unintelligible. His Southern growl forbids the viewer from understanding a damn word he's saying....and that's only the "good" guys. The "bad" guys are no better. Three of them serve absolutely no purpose. Since I am not an intimate fan of the comics, I am unaware of their purpose. However, in the movie, they are neither intimidating nor powerful in any noticeable way. Who will stop the Ghost Rider?? Generic henchman-man who plows a semi into a train to phase the Ghost Rider? A puddle monster whose powers of grabbing feet in the form of a puddle and making scary faces surely could have stopped the Ghost Rider? The furious wind demon who has the undeniably superb ability to fly around and be bad-as-hell? I was more worried that Blaze would die from his motorcycle wheel bashing his helmet in on his face. All the enemies were easily expendable except for "Blackheart" around who the movie is based. Yet, his performance remained so lackluster throughout the movie even his role in the movie is questionable. Even Peter Fonda as the devil cannot imbue the dirt of this movie. The struggle for hell never materializes due to Blackheart's wimpy demeanor versus Peter Fonda's obvious experience. Unfortunately, the director wanes from the Ghost Rider storyline of this movie involving Blackheart too often to give Eva Mendes' boobs another close up. Lastly, the facial expression of the random mugger as the Ghost Rider confronts him was priceless; check it out if you do in fact rent this movie.The technicalities of this movie mostly fizzle along with the acting. The special effects were decent if not at times good. However, the writing. That script must have been written by a five year old fan of the comics with ADHD. Continuity that would have tied all of the loose ends together does not exist. The movie jumps from one scene to the other seamlessly...literally. The movie fell apart, quickly. Some of the details regarding stab wounds and gunshots do not pan out either. Someone with the powers of the devil, vulnerable to knives, but not bullets, and performing death-defying jumps across football fields over helicopters without any Satanic input? I think not.Do not suspend disbelief to fall captive to the world forged by this horrible script. This movie would make a good replacement for sleeping pills. I found myself simultaneously falling asleep and laughing my ass off over the whole debacle. It's not worth the time or the effort to get off your butt and rent this horrible film. However, I HIGHLY suggest this film if you are about to have a party where everybody laughs at sorry excuses for movies in a Mystery Science Theater 3000 fashion. Lord have mercy.

Review title: The worst movie experience I have had in a long time.
Review_body: There are reviews that say, "The plot wasn't gripping and the characters didn't bring a tear to my eye", and there are those that say, "If that is what you are after in this kind of film, you are missing the point."To me, the point of a movie is to be entertained. To hear a story, if not a good one--at least one well told. To have fun.There are films that are bad, but still a good time because of the feeling you have when you leave the theater. Then there are bad films which are so incompetent that they make you more cautious about how you really want to spend your time.This film was bad in every way that matters, unless special effects are your reason for living.The dialog is so jarringly terrible, a viewer almost expects every line to end with a smile--to be part of some joke before they get on with their real lines. The actors seem bored and uninspired in their roles, and Nicholas Cage seems wooden even for... Well, even for Nicholas Cage.If it weren't for movies like National Treasure, I would have sworn to never see another Cage film again. I do not know how any actor's agent let them have a part in this movie without a letter of resignation, but this happens sometimes. Look up "Gigli" and "88 Minutes" for other examples.Please do not pay money for this movie. Viewing it is like pushing rusty carpenter nails into your abdomen. It is so bad that it is a running joke among everyone I know. When a bad movie is released, we say, "Well, it isn't Ghost rider, but it was still crap." Avoid this movie. For the children.

Viewers all around the theater were leaning forward on most scenes, if not grabbing their drinks or popcorn, or settling down after and exciting part!The film literally captures the audiences attention to leave you with more. The comic books were well followed, unlike some movie-series, and that alone made it good to watch! I'll be surprised if they don't make a sequel to this beauty-of-a-masterpiece!

Review title: Above Expectations, but still just OK.
Review_body: So this movie wasn't disappointing because pretty much my expectations for the movie was for another Fantastic 4 Debacle. Honestly, it wasn't a great movie, and I don't think I could stretch it to be a "good movie" but I have to say it wasn't that bad. The imagery was pretty sweet at times, the plot moved along so I wasn't bored, and the story wasn't horrible. GASP. This isn't the negative post I expected to write. But there was SOMETHING horrible in the movie. Yes... You guessed it Mr. Coppala himself, Nicholas Cage. OK, horrible may be a bit too strong. I think the word for it is annoying. What the heck is up with his mouth! I can't stop looking at it and wondering if his teeth and lips are real. Actually if I didn't know him before this movie I may have thought him to be funny or perhaps have good timing, but nope. Can't do it. I guess this blog falters in equality. He is ripped like a GI Joe in this movie, so he looks the part. But something just doesn't click for me.The problem I really had with this movie (other than Roxy's shirt popping open in every scene--honestly it was a little much) (and the whole cheese factor) (and the whole Texas factor) was the ending. I have a much better ending which is far more tragic and believable, but would still lend itself to sequels to satisfy the companies behind the Benjamins. For those of you looking for a grade, I refuse to put a grade on this movie out of principle. But if you went and saw it I wouldn't hate you for it.

What are the popular or well-known supernatural heros or legends from the comic world? I believe they are the Spiderman, Batman, Superman, Daredevil, Constantine, the Fantastic Four, the X-Men, etc. But recently, there is another supernatural legend appearing on screen from Hollywood's Marvel comic books which I have not seen before. It is the "Ghost Rider"."It's said that the West was built on legends. Tall tales that help us make sense of things too great or too terrifying to believe. This is the legend of the Ghost Rider." The movie began with these attractive sentences.According to the DVD of this movie, the comic books of the Ghost Rider was first published in the 50's. It was changed and being popular since the 70's. The story of it was modified or edited to make a movie.The movie story was about a brave stunt biker, Johnny Blaze(Nicolas Cage). He sold his soul to the devil dealer, Mephistopheles(Peter Fonda), in order to save his father, Barton Blaze(Brett Cullen), who was also a stunt biker. After signing the contract "Pactum Pactorum", Johnny Blaze owned a power of controlling the hellfire, gained a skill called the "penance stare" to burn the souls of the evils. But that power also made him painful as being cursed. Every night he would change into a monster-like skeleton which was on fire, wearing on a black leather hell-styled jacket, riding on a cool Hellcycle, carrying on a metal chain attached on the jacket.Johnny Blaze was good in possess but he was influenced by that evil curse. He aimed to own this curse or power to save the innocents. He tried to stop Blackheart(Wes Bentley), accompanied with Gressil, Wallow and Abigor, to steal the "Contract of San Vengaza" which carried a thousand of evil souls in order to increase his power. That contract was kept by the Caretaker(Sam Elliott).There was a funny love story about reincarnation in it. Roxanne Simpson(Eva Mendes), who was Johnny Blaze's long lost love, met him again after 56000 years! About the soundtrack or musics, some classic songs from the Carpenters were used. The theme song was the "(Ghost) Riders In The Sky", by Spiderbait.There are choices to make in our life. I think the nice visual effects and the surround sound, with this legendary story and the beautiful comics of the Ghost Rider". it is one of a good choice for people who like comics or movies.

Review title: Ghost Rider: The Spirit of Vengeance "Spoilers"
Review_body: Tonight I went to see Ghost Rider with two friends one of which is an avid comic book fan as am I. Personally we all enjoyed this movie thoroughly and loved how they did justice to the character. The movie entertained me the entire time and kept me in my seat. Ghost Rider the character was great and in his Rider form was completely awesome. Mephistopheles was perfect in the role he played and I prefer him as he was in the film. Similar to how he was in the comic. Blackheart and the fallen angels were great villains and added a great element to the film. Personally I would have liked to see Blackheart in the demon form but otherwise Bentley did a good job. The action and battle scenes were great and Rider's use of the penance stare is something that I loved and never thought they would add.To start off we need to realize one thing when watching movies based off of comic books and graphic novels. They are fictional and should not be taken to be things that actually occur in the real world. This movie was awesome and points about Blaze jumping a football field being impossible should be disregarded. It's a movie and is not true and you should not attempt to apply these things to the real world. The movie is supposed to be entertaining as it was, not translatable to things that actually happen.That said this movie did justice to the character of Ghost Rider and Cage did a great job honoring that character. Eva Mendes, alright she's not Meryl Streep but she still did a decent job with the character. The Caretaker was a great addition in the movie and Blackheart and Mephistopheles were great in the roles they played in this movie. Mephistopheles was played perfectly in this movie and the way his character ends is perfect. Cage is an Academy Award winning actor, why does everyone hate him? He did a great job in this role and in a comic to film adaptation I'd rather see an actor take a leap and actually try and portray the character correctly as Cage did.Let's add the fact that the writers decided to keep the origin as it was which is something that should be done in every comic to film adaptation. Unlike Fantastic Four and others. Also, anyone catch "My name is Legion, for we are many" loved it. This movie did a great job of sticking with the character as he was in the comic for the most part. The character could have been a bit darker however to do a movie it needs to appeal to a mass audience and as the Rider he was dark enough. The penance stare, the chain and the hellfire added a great element and I loved every minute of it. His use of the penance stare added a great element that I never dreamed the writers would use in a million years.Some of the problems people see with this movie are things that should be left out of the discussion on some aspects. Such as the complaints about Ghost Rider in water not extinguishing the flames. Its hellfire not literal fire and therefore doesn't burn out like regular fire. His stunt show tricks are just those tricks and although they may not translate literally into the real world they shouldn't. They should be heightened to extend the drama and excitement of the film. We don't go in expecting the movie to be about actual things that happen every day. Personally I don't see guys riding around with their skulls on fire or shooting people with webs (Had to reference spidey). This movie did what I wanted it too and more, it kept me in my seat the entire time aching for more and more. It was entertaining, exciting and done awesome and I wish they'd stick close to the characters more often as they did here.Let me say one thing though. The plot line is not meant to apply to the real world. Not to mention you people claiming you knew what was going the happen, unless you've read a Ghost Rider comic before you don't know. How in God's name did you know he'd use the penance stare to destroy Blackheart before he enveloped all the souls. How did you know that he was going to absorb the souls as he did. I have read the comic and I was still entertained even as I knew what would happen in the end.Personally it is rare to find a comic to film adaptation that actually hits the character as it was in the comic. My buddy and I could not get enough of how well they did that in this movie. Cage did what he should have done, the character justice. This movie does not contain academy award winning acting but how many films actually do. There are numerous entertaining films that don't have the highest level of acting however they do what they are supposed and keep you entertained and this movie did this for me. Cage and Mendes had good chemistry on screen and Wes Bentley, Sam Elliot and Peter Fonda were great in their roles. Personally Donal Logue is one of my favorite actors and his character went along well with Blaze.I rank this as one of the greatest comic adaptations they have done and I would rank it up there with Batman Begins and Spider-man. Anyway this movie did the character great justice and I would see this movie two more times in theaters before going out and buying the DVD the day it comes out. Go watch it. It was awesome."Your soul has been tainted by the blood of the innocent. Look into my eyes and feel their pain." The penance stare was awesome!

Review title: Why I gave this two out of ten....
Review_body: I'm afraid there's not much intelligent to be said about this film. May I begin with addressing some critics who believe that this film's plot is thin. I disagree outright; the plot is not thin, it is non-existent. I have no further commentary on the issue; to me, the plot was about as discernible as the producer's reasons for releasing the film at all. I reserve criticisms of the plot to those who want to waste their time noting the film's infinite number of failings in that area. I don't.Also, the punchlines and one-liners that litter this movie are not just hackneyed, not just boring, not just mediocre, and not just outright predictable - they are poorly executed as well. If you're going to throw in a cheesy one-liner comeback (this film is guilty of all too many instances of this), at least execute it fashionably or be original in one way or another. There is no attempt to be original here; quite the contrary, it appears as though this film sets out to cherry-pick the weakest and most predictable one-liners from the cesspool of hero-villain Motion Pictures and then attempt the seemingly impossible: make them worse. All else aside, this film deserves credit just for pulling off this feat.Again I must disagree with critics: Ghost Rider is actually funny. I personally cried from a fit of laughter when the "Ghost Rider"'s skull was set on fire, no seriously, this was so ridiculous it was funny. Sure it was in the comic and whatever, but give me a break - at least make the damn thing scary, not some flame-headed clown to be laughed at! The dark guy (I don't even remember his name, that's how forgettable the characters in this film are) also offers some comic relief with his gross overacting, thoroughly deserving of a part in Buffy the Vampire Slayer. No really, we get it, he's evil - cut the snake voice, satanic laugher and dark glances every two seconds, it's beyond a joke.So what about the screenplay and acting? Well, to be fair, from Nicholas Cage through to Eva Mendes, the performances were not disappointing. They were far beyond that; in fact, disappointing would be a compliment. No more sugarcoating: from Mendes' fake breasts, female cliché (even that was poorly executed!) and forced dialog to Cage's botox-ed face, perpetually half-asleep daze and, of course, misfitted role, the acting just plain sucked.To rub salt into the wounds, the soundtrack was like being hit by a train, and not in a good, Metallica kind of way, just a downright, pure and simple shredding of the eardrum, pounding of the skull, I-want-to-leave-the-cinema kind of way. Guitar riffs, fifty-decibel-too-loud orchestral pieces mixed with shrieks of the undead really aren't a good mix, trust me on this one.So why did I give this film two stars when it deserved none? One for the special effects. The other for sheer astonishment - for the fact that, despite the director's blatant incapacity to make a film worth watching, a generous budget was nevertheless acquired for its production. This film should go down in history just for that awesome piece of cajoling on whoever's part it was. Amazing con-artistry. Kudos.Otherwise, this is honestly the worst movie ever made.

What can i truly say about this movie. It's a full on 8. Not the best but does not disappoint. What can I truly say about this movie? It's a full on 8. Not the best but does not disappoint. Nick Cage does a wonderful job of playing Johnny Blaze. The rest of the cast are all not good but not bad. Sam Elliot is the only other exception. His voice, his acting, his presence just fit the "western" part of the move and I can't see a better choice.The movie combines 2 genres: action and western. The film is an action film but it base is a western type of story. The soundtrack boosts the aforementioned roots with classic Wild West movie sounds. The Ghost rider even says "Eeeha!" while spinning his chain as a lasso. It's been said that it has horror movie in it. All I can say is a definite NO. Yes people die but not that horrific. It steals a little from Constantine in the "devil" department but I didn't really mind.It's a very good Superhero movie. I give it a full on 8. Daredevil as we know was crap. Electra was the son of that crap. Spidey 2 left a sour taste in the mouth, so did X3 and Superman Returns we all know that that is one Superman that should be shot. Ghost rider was surprisingly good.My suggestion: Watch it and make your own decision. Don't flame it as a 0 star movie because as I mentioned there are a lot worse out there. It's what I call a "Saturday night Movie": enjoyable, fun and entertaining.

Review title: First trailer I saw intrigued me, movie was trash.
Review_body: Whenever a comic book becomes a movie, odds are that it will be disappointing. Batman, Batman Returns, the original Superman movies, Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, Sin City, were good. Ghost Rider, X-Men, Spiderman, Batman Begins, all fit in one category, Crap. Most of these movies directly avoid following the same plots and stories that made the comics great to begin with.I went with friends and watched this movie, and I want my 2 hours and 12 dollars back. No plot, no dialog, cheese-fest film. The only thing I enjoyed from this was the initial crash in slow-mo, and Daisy Fuentes.It's clear that Nick Cage didn't read the script, he was just a fan of the Ghost Rider comic book.It's up to you, but don't waste your time and money watching this drivel.

Step aside Uwe we've got a new player in the game of "let's slap together an uninspired and down right flat movie based off a licensed IP". This is one of those movies where characters do things, and plots move forward "just cuz". It's mostly Nick Cage sitting around and looking like he made a big mistake, and I think that mistake is he sold his soul for a flourishing early career with the likes of the Cohen Bros. and David Lynch , and it's lost him his hairline and put him in this movie, which as an audience member is a pretty close simulation of a boring and unendurable hell. Characters talk their feelings, the action comes across as an afterthought, and nothing is surprising; a five year old could guess each turn of events. The only lasting effect of this movie is that for the last day or so I've been wondering to myself as to why was Peter Fonda in it? If you're over 12 don't go see this movie.

Review title: The absolute WORST movie I have ever seen
Review_body: This was ridiculously bad. The acting was horrendous, the special effects were garbage as was the plot. I walked out of the theater feeling like I had just wasted over an hour of my life. There is NO story, no emotion, NOTHING. Please do not waste your money on this movie. I normally don't criticize movies like this, and like movies a lot of people might think are bad, but this is going too far. This movie should not have been released. It was incredibly drawn out, which isn't surprising given the fact that they had to take no story and stretch it over a couple of hours. The previews make it look bad enough, but if you see the movie you will discover the degree of awfulness this movie possesses. Take my word, don't put yourself through it. I'm sorry, but any person who enjoyed this movie is at the same level intellectually as a two-year-old.

When the first previews for this movie came out, I was so excited. Boy, was I disappointed. It starts off well enough, and then takes a full nosedive into stupidity. Nicolas Cage was okay as the lead, but the actress opposite him (whose name I don't remember intentionally) was HORRIBLE. I wouldn't believe she was even a reporter for a UHF channel. There were some funny moments, and the special effects were great, but the good is obliterated by the bad in my opinion. I was really annoyed with the screenplay. The dialogue was stupid, Sam Elliot was completely wasted, and the final climactic fight was almost an EXACT replica of the final fight scene in the movie Blade. Try to watch the end of this movie and not think of Blade. I bet you'll giggle once you see what I'm talking about. Bet me. ;)Super mega turkey, with all the trimmings. What a waste.

Review title: An average Summer-esquire comic book flick
Review_body: Not in league with Spider-man or Batman Begins, but still a fun movie to watch. Could have used a lot more action, but what was there was fine with me, showed a small taste of the heroes power. Nic Cage had some small moments where his acting reminded me of the wickerman, but all in all he did a good job.I enjoyed the movie, it was pretty fast paced, which kept me interested throughout, not really any boring moments. I saw what could have been a plot hole or two but honestly, it's just a comic book movie, I didn't expect it to be a masterpiece or anything. I enjoyed it and I think most of your average movie-goers liked it also for what it is.This movie is more on par with Fantastic 4 and Blade:Trinity (the first 2 were fantastic though) than some of the other comic book based films, such as Batman begins, a great movie with dark elements I had expected to be in Ghost rider, which seemed a little bit toned down to me, one of my only complaints was the lack of "disturbing" elements.So, if you have some free time on your hands and you want to be entertained for 2 hours, enjoy Ghost Rider if you haven't all ready seen it.

Review title: Ghost Rider was disappointing to say the least but Cage was still awesome
Review_body: It's funny because it seems that no one really likes reading a good review of a movie. Good reviews add too much hype to a movie and there's not enough interesting material to make it a good read. A bad review on the other hand can add so much to a movie that it can make even the worst movie good. A bad review is chock full of the author's loathsome feelings towards the movie. It is full of obscure and strange, yet hilarious metaphors about what the author was experience during the time of viewing. They're just... better So, having said that I got the privilege of sitting through a, I'm going to use the word, magnificent film: Ghost Rider. The film begins and we see young Johnny Blaze... yes, Blaze... I know, but it is in fact just a coincidence that his last name is Blaze and has NOTHING to do with the fact that his head turns into a blazing skull. Nothing at all. Now, Johnny has just learned that his dad has cancer. But, don't worry... help is on the way in the form of none other than: Mephistopheles. Help has taken its form in none other than Satan himself. He offers to cure Blaze's dad in return for his soul. Sure, it couldn't hurt right? WRONG! Satan starts to be a real bitch when the next day he kills Blaze's dad in a "motorcycle accident'... Now, he can be a real dick, but do not call him a contract breaker or a liar... for he did neither. So, he tells Blaze that sometime in his life he will call upon him to be his slave, or "the rider", and do chores for him like vacuum hell, fix the drapes, and collect escaped souls... you know the usual.Flash forward into the future... Blaze is now a famous motorcycle rider who jumps cars and stuff. This is actually the part of the movie that is interesting. He meets his long lost love and they chat and reminisce and just when Blaze thinks he's getting some hot, sweet, Latino loving... the devil calls on him to "ride"! Man... how inconvenient! The devil sticks Blaze on a chopper  an evil chopper  and he will be called Ghost Rider. The reason he needs to ride is Satan's son Blackheart... ha ha not a coincidental name also... has escaped from hell and is threatening to destroy the earth and blah blah blah... boring plot stuff that I'm sure you're not interested in. Now, here's where the movie turns... as does Blaze... into Ghost Rider. He has to go out and defeat Blackheart and his other cronies and send them back to hell in exchange for his soul back. I don't know about you guys but this storyline sounds very familiar doesn't it... can somebody say Schindler's List? The four cronies end up at a train station... the conductor walks out of the control room holding none other than a lantern. A lantern? We can figure out how to bring souls back from hell, but no one has invented a flashlight yet? Then a tumbleweed rolls by. I'm sorry is this 1812 with motorcycles? And don't even get me started on the whole exaggerated finger-pointing fetish he has (for those who have seen it... they know what I'm talking about). So Ghost Rider shows up with computer generated graphics that look so real I find I keep looking at my hands to see if a Playstation controller isn't resting safely in them. All the while Ghost Rider is aided in his quest by a local cemetery caretaker, who pretty conveniently knows everything there is about Ghost Riders, and gives him clues to help him. Thank goodness, right? This is where I black out and dream of happier things like snakebites and stepping on nails, and being in a room with Fran Dresher for 48 hours. I did, however, catch a part where Ghost Rider gets to speak. I'm not sure when Johnny Blaze, cool, literate, clear speaking motorcycle rider got to turn into Ghost Rider the animated, illiterate, half-retarded, skull face with down syndrome! I got the privilege of hearing him say such wonderful phrases like "You... Guilty" and "Go...To... Hell" in a real "Me Tarzan You Jane" sort of manner. The type of lines that you could find only in the funniest of Shakespeare. Haha... oh that guy. When I wake up from my blackout I get to see Ghost Rider pull his"badass" on-fire motorcycle out of a lake with him still riding on it... real Tokyo Drift Style. Bow Wow would be proud. The rest of the movie is just a blur of loud noises and the color orange. By the end of the movie... and I hope I'm not spoiling it for anyone... Ghost Rider has stopped Blackheart and is offered his soul back by the devil. Unfortunately for the devil, Blaze isn't ready to give up that easily. He decides to stay the Ghost Rider to fight the devil forever, kill him and metaphorically make him his bitch. The devil gives the best line of the movie with a long, extended "Noooooooooo". When really I could tell he was thinking "Damn it! I gave him the power... why didn't I make it so I could take it back! Son of a bitch... I can't believe I'm that fickle! Oh bother!" Now, don't get me wrong, Nicolas Cage is one of my favorite actors of all time. And the movie was actually pretty decent when Ghost Rider was not involved, but other than that I've had a better time being sodomized in Mexico by a bandit who was only trying to rob me but unfortunately the night before I lost my wallet while tying up a Mexican stripper and beating her to death with a rock. So, I guess see it... if you want... but maybe just do something more exciting like stealing from the blind.

The effects and soundtrack also really added a lot to the movie. I was so looking forward to this movie when I first saw the trailer. I even marked the release date on my calendar. Unfortunately, I was somewhat disappointed. The story and concept is great, but the overall execution of the movie was subpar. I've seen other movies that Nicholas Cage and Eva Mendes have acted in, so I can fairly say that the Ghostrider screenplay is totally at fault here. Can anyone say "Velveeta"? Some parts were totally cheesy. The editing was poor in some areas. The pace was lackluster and dull--this is my biggest pet peeve about Ghostrider. There were odd, long pauses in the movie. It was like waiting for a punch-line that never came.I had such high hopes for this movie. I would strongly recommend a remake! Find a better script and a better director...and I'll be there for the next version.

I went into this movie with high hopes, I have read the GR comics and was expecting big things, especially since the release date was put back a year so the fight scene's can be improved. Oh how disappointed I was.The whole movie was slow and when it came to an action scenes it was over within 30 seconds. You would think these big Hollywood script writers could have come up with a better fight scene between the Devils Bounty Hunter that has a flaming skull for a head, an fallen angels that are hiding in the elements. But all that seemed to happen was he walked up to them did the penance stare and that was it. 20-30 seconds tops per fight scene. Also the fight scene between GR and the helicopter that took so long to make, was useless. There was no fight. He wrapped his chain around the helicopter pulled it in then let it go. How that was so long in the making is ridiculous.And at the end when the Devil said he would take back the curse an Johnny Blaze said no I'm going to use it against you. The Devil screamed and disappeared. You would think the Devil with all that power an the contract being completed he would do what ever he wants. No matter what Johnny said, the contract was completed so why didn't he just take the powers back and kill them both, he's the Devil its the kind of thing that he would do.I just feel the whole movie was poor, I was very disappointed.

Review title: a B-movie with A-actors acting like in C-commercials
Review_body: If it would not have been for Nicolas Cage this movie would hardly even make it in the theatres but straight to the B-movie section of your next video store. Very poor acting. Luckily Eva Mendes has a nice cleavage, which helped over a few scenes. And Nicolas Cage - great actor as he is - at least let you hope that he is going to say something noteworthy - unfortunately he disappoints. Actions scenes, special effects: been there, done that - nothing new and impressive enough to keep you alert. Mask and makeup: without any doubt very impressive - for a horror movie produced in the sixties. All together a very predictable movie with a very predictable plot that made me yawn several times.
