This movie altered my life, for the better. It's a harrowing tale of a young man growing up in chaos and strife, and the fact that he makes it out alive in the end as a stronger individual really spoke to me.If it's too late for Ghost Rider to win an Oscar this year, then I'm sure we'll be seeing this title popping up all over the place next year.I can't wait for the sequel. A trilogy would be nice.***WARNING: SPOILER AHEAD!!!!!***"You may have taken my soul, but you'll never take my spirit!" ... Beautiful.

I've never read any of the original Ghost Rider comics, so I didn't go into this film with any preconceived notions. I don't know how accurate it is to the original, or how the comedy and action balance out with what has been established in the comics. All I do know is that it was an enjoyable film, and I was thoroughly entertained. Isn't that all a movie is supposed to be? I have highly recommended this film to all of my friends, but I must warn you: if you're not used to horror pictures, this one has a few horror elements, so brace yourself for some unpleasant stuff. Other than that, the action was exciting, the humor was funny and the romance, although a little over the top, was sweet. This film garners a solid 8 out of 10.

Review title: The Most I've Laughed In Ages
Review_body: ... which is bad when the movie you are watching isn't a comedy. The script is cheesy, the acting is hammed up at best - when it is not just God awful, and the action sequences were not even exciting. The plot sucked as well. Skip unless you enjoy movies that are so bad they make you laugh. Which it DOES deliver.The ending makes you cringe and want to lash out at the screen. Nicholas Cage's head is CGI-ed onto a younger man's body at one point to give him six pack abs.The villain is not even scary nor does he present a real fight or dilemma. I also could not figure out why "Johnny Blaze" had an accent while his girlfriend did not even though she was from the same area as him.The movie was one big action genre cliché, gone bad. Skip the $10 and wait until it debuts on TV sometime.

Review title: An entertaining, visually pleasing all be it cheesy comic adaption
Review_body: A lot of people don't like it, mostly everyone who I know who has seen it found it mildly entertaining at the very best. Most just straight up hated it and think it's a poor attempt at making what could have been an incredible film. I, on the other hand rather enjoyed it. If you can get to grips with the fact that its about a man who change's into a guy with a flaming skull for a head, and the mildly humorous one liners which make the film extremely cheesy then you should enjoy it. The story line isn't up to much, and the enemies are easily defeated in what can only be described as incredibly stupid ways that make you think, "What was the point in them?" With that said, if you go expecting a cheesy, action packed film, which is clearly there to simply entertain you, not like some other films, which set out to lull you into thinking this could actually happen in reality for the duration of the film, then you should enjoy it. Just a few words about the storyline's inability to please many of the films critics. With 'Ghost Rider' not being a highly popular comic in the Marvel chain the story had to be improvised quite a lot. With that being said, the writers have done a fantastic job on the storyline, with plenty of action and plenty of scenes as Johnny Blaze as the Ghost Rider. Nicholas Cage (Johnny Blaze/ Ghost Rider), although not exactly challenged by this role, makes it his own and makes it as realistic as is possible for you to believe his character, who essentially is a man who becomes the Devil's Bounty Hunter by night. Finally, I come to the question is it worth going to see? Well my opinion, which is one of a person who enjoyed the film is yes go and see it on the big screen and then buy it on DVD. I know I'm going to be getting it on DVD at some point in the near future, probably on its release date. Having read this review, it is up to you weather you think it's worth going to see or just waiting for it to come out on DVD. Either way I suggest you watch it to make your own mind up about it. Don't just take the word of the people around you, from this review you should be able to realise weather you will enjoy it or weather it is not for you. Just remember...don't expect a highly intellectual film with outstanding acting performances and an incredibly believable storyline because you will come away disappointed. It is merely, in my opinion, a fun, action packed, COMIC BOOK based film, made to simply entertain.

Review title: This movie needs Cro and Tom Servo
Review_body: When I got a free pass to a prescreening of Ghost Rider at my comic shop, I was thrilled. I'd already been planning on seeing it, as I am a fan of the character, and I typically enjoy Nicolas Cage movies. The trailers I'd seen had not filled me with hope, so I was expecting a bad, but still enjoyable movie, along the same lines of Daredevil and X-Men 3. I was thoroughly disappointed.The movie began, and I was entertained to see that they were including the original western Ghost Rider in the story, even if they had to completely change the character in order to do so. The movie continued, and I was further impressed that they got Johnny Blaze's origin story right. My nervousness about the quality of the movie began to subside. But then the movie continued further.It seems that part of the Ghost Rider curse is constant pointing and the spouting of one liners. To say nothing of the re-use of CGI. I don't know how many times I saw the same clip of Ghost Rider flipping his chain around his torso to put it away. Some other reviews have said that the fights were excellent. What fights? I don't know what movie they saw, but I did not see any fights that lasted longer than several seconds.As I said, my ticket to see the movie was free. I want my gas money refunded. And leaving the theater, I was not the only person muttering that. Nor were we in the minority.All in all, all I can say is "Mark Steven Johnson, your soul is tainted with the blood of the innocent. Look into my eyes."

To categorize this movie as a super-hero film would be wrong. Although it does come from the comic book genre it came off as anything but a a superhero film. The movie did succeed in bringing to life Ghost Rider, with a choice selection on the character of Johnny Blaze, however the movie lacked real 'substance'. There were no real power struggles. First off, i only saw Black Heart as the quasi-gay obsessive freak from American Beauty which often had me observing his character and thinking 'definitely not a part for him', and often annoyed by it. but i digress. When Ghost Rider encountered the 'Hidden' ? were they called. the first time. he got rid of one. ran into Mr. wind. got rid of him in 2 seconds. and then Mr. water boiled him yadda yadda. Wheres the battle? there was no real fighting. All ghost rider did was walk around.... make stuff burn... and then do his soul burning thing. i figured him controlling his power would be a plot'ish point when he read it in the book, and hed fail at controlling it. buttttttt no. he goes 'i want to control you' and poof! fire hand. wow... suspense there! i actually caught myself staring out my window at one point. also what bothered me was he didn't get his soul back.... hes going to burn in hell... all for what appeared to me IMMEDIATELY was a cheap shot at a possible sequel. LAME. this movie was done almost completely wrong. another thing that bothered me. the 'caretaker' basically showed himself as 'a ghost rider' and then ran away. i was laughing. i actually said out loud... 'you mean that was it?' he just....rode off. total waste. ugh, so many things bothered me. like.... why would 4 cop cars show up and point guns, when they find a license plate? thats called a LEAD. you follow up on leads, you don't show up guns drawn. plus 'Johnny Blaze' is now a fugitive and his life is ruined and everyone knows hes some fire skull freak, im sure his father would be proud. im going to go have a brain aneurysm now.

Review title: A good movie, not a great movie
Review_body: I went to go see Ghost Rider a couple of weeks ago and I am pleased to say that I quite enjoyed it. I had been waiting for this movie for years, as I am a long time Ghost Rider fan, and I was glad that they waited until now to make it. The CG was able to do justice to the changes that John Blaze undergoes to become the Ghost Rider, and the changes in the Hellcycle bridge the gap between the original 1970's inspired chopper and today's updated choppers.I did spoil the movie a bit for myself as I had read a number of reviews and user comments before going into the movie, and so I was thinking of what others had said as I was watching the movie. Nicholas Cage's quirky sense of humour and delivery were a good match for the John Blaze character. Peter Fonda was too restrained as Mephistopheles. Wes Bently was excellent as Blackheart, as he captured the spirit of the character. Eva Mendes was OK as Roxanne, but the character was never a focus in the comics, and so her part in the movie was also minimal.Ghost Rider, the character, was always a second tier comic in the Marvel Universe, so the movie is not in the blockbuster category of Spider-Man or X-Men. I think there is a good possibility for a sequel, as there are a number of other characters from the Ghost Rider series that could be introduced, especially as the movie took elements from the original John Blaze Ghost Rider, as well as the newer Dan Ketch Ghost Rider.Overall, I thought this movie was good fun and quite enjoyed it.

Review title: Worst Comic Book Film (and worst film period)
Review_body: Now, I love comic book films and I love Ghost Rider and I have to say, quite honestly, that this is not only the worst comic book film I have ever seen it is in the running for the top 5 worst films I have ever seen in my life. It is the first movie I have ever watched at a theater and honestly felt that I should get my money back (and I am quite forgiving). There is no redeeming feature about Ghost Rider. The casting is TERRIBLE. The script is COMPLETE TRASH. The soundtrack SUCKS. The acting is Horrendous, though I think it is not so much the actors' fault as the director and scriptwriter. The only parts of the movie that were even redeemable in any TINY fashion were a couple funny lines that had absolutely nothing to do with the movie at all. Honestly folks, I would almost never do this, but really, really, REALLY, DON'T WASTE YOUR TIME or YOUR MONEY!!! The entire audience left the theater in a really somber and clearly unsatisfied manner. Don't let that be you. Don't even bother to wait and rent it. It's GARBAGE!!!

I noticed that a lot of people are hating on this movie so i figured it's time to set things straight:1.Script: It's an action movie made after a comic book series, so don't watch the movie expecting a script a la "Pursuit of Hapyness", "Little Miss Sunshine" etc. (you get the picture).Doing that it's just plain stupid.2.Acting: Nicholas Cage does a great job bringing Johnny Blaze to life.One thing is clear: the man knows how to act and proves that he's one of the best Hollywood has to offer.The "funny moments" in the film could of been easily transformed into embarrassing and "cheesy" ones but Cage does again a very, very good job (there were moments when the whole cinema was laughing).Eva Mendes does exactly what i was expecting: looking good and displaying "decent" acting skills.There is however allot of room for improvement.3.Visual Effects: Superb.This film has so many awesome CGI scenes that you should watch it two or three times in order to fully appreciate them but....yes there is a but.....in a couple of close-ups the Rider's skull looks kind of awkward.However the movie more than makes up for them. This is one of the best comic book based movies ever made.It stands right there with X-Men 2,definitely better then The Last Stand and probably a little under Batman Begins.So put your preconceptions aside and go watch the movie for what it is : a Marvel based movie with a good cast and strong visual effects.You will have a blast!

Review title: I am Leeeeggiioooon because we are manyyy...!
Review_body: Everything about this movie was so clichéd. Just to mention a few,1. Hero's good friend, innocent ol' Mack (Donal Loque, the only saving grace from the movie), would get the obligatory "shock" value treatment (see the sheriff from "Misery"), 2. The "I am Legion...." (as per this summary title) cry at the convergence of spirits was so campy, and i thought it could have done with a more sinister / scarier / demonic punchline, seriously, did Blackheart have to explain what Legion meant? It's like "I'm Ghost Rider, because I'm A Ghost that Rides!!!!" 3. Villains get killed too easily, no-brainer task for the hero, 4. The original Ghost Rider (Sam Elliot's Slade) was not fully expounded upon, it was like they ran out of cash halfway or something,5. No ground-breaking CGI's here folks (unrelated to the topic, i know). Some scenes really look cheap. 6. The bad guy in this case, Mephistopheles (excellently portrayed by Peter Fonda, if i may add) obligatory end scene that runs along the line of "oh, so you're not doing your part of the deal huh? See in you in the sequel then" 7. The end, where the obligatory, hero / transformation scene, paving the way for sequels, here Johnny Blaze winks to show that he can...before........(I won't reveal the spoilers out of respect), but see how tastefully Batman Begins left it open to sequel(s).Here's to Chris Nolan's re-imagining of "Ghost Rider Begins"! :) Awful, i wanted to blow my brains out (just kidding). A lot of reviews praised this movie on the basis that it's just a darn comic. But this is Nic Cage we're talking about, and we know he doesn't really need the money, but i hope they save the Ghost Rider / Devil (please, Mr. Fonda, come back provided Chris Nolan comes onboard) confrontation for the best.But hands up, those who thought the casting of Raquel Alessi as a young Eva Mendez was spot on?...

Review title: Buck-toothed Blaze and the movie I shouldn't have seen.
Review_body: This movie was horrible, its only redeeming value is the special effects and when "The Caretaker," Sam Elliot, is in the scene. This movie had so much potential and fell extremely short. I was expecting a VERY DARK movie that I waited quite awhile for and instead I get "Ghost Rider" - a light-hearted tale with a cheesy love story. I saw the movie and was shocked, I wanted to leave halfway though but I paid $9.50 so I had to stay. To tell you the truth I kept hoping it was going to get better but it didn't. The movie has great foundational ideas about coming to grips with the "darkness inside of you" and if "executed correctly" could have been better than Batman Begins - but they took a very adult storyline and tailored it to seventh-graders. By "seventh-graders" I mean this: the dialogue had no "big words" and no intellectual depth; the characters act as if "a flaming skull-demon-man" isn't the scariest damn thing they have ever seen (i.e. there is even a joke about the flaming-skull during the movie); the "demons" in the film look "scary" at different points for no reason, it doesn't fit the tone of the movie, I can only guess it provides a "quick trill" to the little kids watching; Eva Mendes bouncing breasts were particularly annoying in the movie and undoubtedly fueled the fantasies of countless hormone imbalanced teenagers, Mendes' breasts are LITERALLY at the center of the screen in EVERY SCENE and her shirt is frequently unbuttoned at least one or two buttons too far which I guess helps provide a distraction to her melodramatic-soap-opera acting style during the film; Matt Long (Young Blaze) is also a horrible actor and ruins the first part of the movie, which sets up the rest of the film to be as equally hard to watch. I will not go into depth about about the different parts of the film I thought were horrible since this is not a "spoiler" review. I will tell you that if you are expecting a good movie that "Ghost Rider" hits very far from the mark. If you can stand the cheesy jokes and melodramatic love story then this film is probably for you; but if you are looking for X-Men, Batman Begins, or Spiderman type quality then this is not your movie.

Well, let me start of by saying that animation / graphics in this movie are breathtaking, but...the actual movie isn't.I really felt like I was watching a movie designed for infants, it was cliché, boring and I felt like I had seen it all before.Maybe it was me but I didn't find anything funny in it at all, maybe it was just me but I only heard like 1 person in the entire theater laughing so maybe it wasn't.The movie was slow in my opinion, it felt like hours before he even 'switched forms' for the first time, and the actor(s) who played the devils were absolute garbage, their acting was pathetic.Overall i don't recommend this movie to anyone, its a waste of 2 hours of your life.

The movie was exciting the entire way through. I waited forever for the movie to come out and I wasn't disappointed. Nicholas Cage, Eva Mendez, Sam Elliot and everyone else did an incredible job. It's only the 17th of Feb. but it's by far the best movie to come out this year that I have seen. I used to read the comics up to a certain point but I'm not anal when they create them to the big screen. I know how it works. I suppose if you are anal and haven't meant reality you will find something to complain about as people do in every movie of this type. After watching Ghost Rider opening night, I will be sure to see it again for sure on the big screen. All in all, great movie.

Ghost Rider is the best movie ever (in my opinion). I watched it as a kid in cinemas when i was 7. The special effects are amazing and i love the acting. Nicolas cage plays his role with confidence and i love him for that. Wes Bentley (Blackheart) also does his role well. I have been hooked in this move all my life. and I'm only 17. Ghost Rider is definitely a movie i recommend you watch. The only down side is that they were suppose to be in Texas but gave the illusion away when Ghost Rider appears on the Melbourne Footbridge But everything else makes up for that little mistake. Marvel did really well with this movie and i love Mark Stephan-Johnson for directing this movie. Good Job. The movie for me gets a 10000/10 Its that good.

Just wanted to clear up that in the plot summary they messed up. he doesn't make the deal for mendes... he makes it for his dad! All the trailers for this movie make it seem like thats what he does it for too but its not. But its a frickin awesome movie and thats coming from a girl who isn't that into comic book movies. check it out if you get the chance. and i agree with the guy that posted the comment that said Don't SAY A MOVIE SUCKS IF YOU Haven't SEEN IT. that is one of my biggest pet peeves lol. i hate that this thing has a min 10 line comment. i don't have 10 lines to say i was just mad because the plot summary was wrong. there i think i have 10 lines now. haha.

I've seen a lot of shitty movies in my life but this is the worst movie ever to hit the movies in my opinion. On the way over to the cinema I thought about the great movies N. Caige has starred in... but I was disappointed. When you see a bad movie you still have some urge in you to see the ending, but there was no urges in my body at all. People actually left the cinema during the movie. The special effects was all rubbish and laughable. If I was to point out one good feature in this movie it would be the ending credits because of two reasons: 1. The movie was over and I could go home. 2. The song 'Ghost Rider'.In summary: The story is worthless and the special effects is rubbish. If possible, stay away from this movie....

May have some spoilers!!! I've seen it...And it's good... Like really good compared to Daredevil (considering this is the movie everyone's comparing Ghost Rider to).The first part is a little too fast, I mean, his dad didn't get much screen time even though he plays a pretty big part in the story. But then again, showing his dad too much would have been a little boring.Eva Mendes was okay, but she showed off a little too much cleavage and seems to walk like a duck (yknow, with her but sticking out waaay too much).The actions scenes were pretty good, the camera angles were great and the emphasis on the characters' movements were awesome. And i love his whole getup, with all the leather and chains and spikes and whatever else biker boys have.Nic Cage acted quite well, i must say. but then again, when he's ghost rider, he doesn't have to act all that much. I mean, he's a flaming skeleton with this deep throaty voice... It could have been Britney Spears and we'd have been convinced he works for the Devil.Oh and the Ghopst Rider himself, man his story is awesome. How often do you see some guy sell his soul and work for the devil and still be a good guy? I mean c'mon, if any of you watch the Collector, most of these people who sell their souls end up pretty frickin' screwed while they're alive.On the effects, the flames were excellent. I love how the fire just does it's thing. It doesn't take your attention away from Ghost rider, but it doesn't just fade into his character, either. Although the Devil's son's ice power was a little... not cool enough. The way he kills his victims is so The Ring. The other three guys, the sand guy, the water guy and the air guy were alright too.So overall, this movie is reaaaally nice. Kinda takes us away from all the city boys and gives us a badass Southern biker boy with kickass fire powers.

Review title: Ghost Rider; Nothing I'd see twice but definitely worth watching Once
Review_body: Let's just get one thing clear: Ghost Rider wasn't great but it wasn't terrible either. In the very least it was entertaining. Yes it doesn't compare to Spiderman or X-Men (The Punisher is the best one of them all) but its better than the likes of Daredevil, Hulk, etc. I think people were let down because like myself the trailer had them sold from day one and this release had been marked on my calender for months. As a result of being let down a lot of people are being pretty harsh. I'd recommend seeing this picture if you'd like to, just, be entertained for a few hours. If your looking to see the best action/comic picture ever made then your going to leave pretty unhappy. Nic Cage is one of the best, there's no denying that, I think he pulls off the Ghost Rider character well. For the males out there Eva Mendes is absolutely gorgeous and there's no denying that either. Her character was undeveloped but being just "eye candy" in this picture is a quite a stretch. A movie like this disappoints me in a lot of ways but in the end I didn't leave the theater like I did after watching Alexander a few years back. I was irate because the trailer made that one look like something great but it was the biggest waste of time and money that I've ever experienced in my life. Ghost Rider was nothing like that. Disappointed sure, irate no. Ultimately what needs to be said is that this film, at its worst, is an average picture. It's not some atrocity that some people are saying it is. Go see it and you'll most likely respond to it the way I did. Just give it a chance. You may love it, like it or hate it. Everybody's critique is unique. This was a vague representation of mine. Oh yeah, I just wanted to say that Nicolas Cage had his finest performance in his finest film; The Family Man. I don't care what you guys say its the truth. Matchstick Men, Leaving Las Vegas and Family Man, all great movies.

Review title: Not what it should've been (spoiliers included)
Review_body: Ghost Rider wasn't a bad movie... It's just flawed in several areas. My #1 beef with this movie is that it feels extremely rushed, and several parts of the plot make no sense. For instance: (Spoiler starts here) Why would Carter Slade (who can only change to rider form ONE more time) change to rider form, and DO Absolutely NOTHING TO HELP BLAZE??? That was the most pointless thing in the movie. He could've just handed the contract to Blaze and said "here take this shotgun with you too", and just left, but no he changed and rode with him, and then upon arriving to their destination changes back, and just disappears??? The one part I loved about this movie was Blackheart. Wes Bently did an amazing job playing Blackheart. Even though they don't really show his true form (it fades in and out at the end), I was amazed. I hope I see more of this actor in other movies.Fight scenes are short and unimpressive with the exception of the police pursuit.At the end of the day, Ghost Rider is an unimpressive attempt at bringing a mediocre comic book hero (more of an anti-hero) to the big screen. It wasn't horrible, but it can't compete with the mainstream franchises. My prediction is there will be no sequel, and to be honest, it doesn't deserve one.

I believe Nicolas Cage is one of the greatest actors around. It is very disappointing to watch him in a movie like this one. This movie is among his worst movies ever! The script is so poor, the jokes are not funny, Nicolas Cage and Eva Mendez are trying to be funny at some point but they are not, simply because the movie and the plot are not helping! Probably Eva Mendez was picked for this movie just because her looks and her fame, but she does not seem like the perfect actress for this role. I wish next movies by Cage are much better.In summary: 1. Adequate Story. 2. Poor Script. 3. The few jokes in there are not funny.

Review title: Everyone thinks they're a movie critic
Review_body: I love Ghost Rider, I've loved it ever since I started reading the comic when I was 13. I mean a guy with a kick-ass motorcycle, bad-ass chains, and his SKULL IS ON FIRE! The premise was completely absurd, but at the same time it was the coolest thing I've ever seen. Over 10 years later, a motorcycle riding, skull flaming, soul banishing bounty hunter from hell is still the coolest thing I've ever heard of.Everyone thinks they're a movie critic, and there have been so many great movies that people have dumped on because they think something, somehow gave them the right to criticize something they couldn't do themselves, or wouldn't like no matter how good it was. If you want to say Ghost Rider was a bad movie, then before your opinion has ANY weight, you have to show me that you could make a better movie, otherwise SHUT UP and let people who love the comic and love the idea go to the movie and have a great time.People love to harp on this movie because of its premise. I hear a lot of Scooby-Doo references, I don't know about you, but I've never seen a flaming skull use a chain to banish evil souls to hell in Scooby-Doo. IGNORE anyone who negatively criticizes this movie because of the premise, completely ignore them, since no matter how good the movie was, they wouldn't like it anyway, and they shouldn't rate it. Don't listen to them, not just for this movie, for ANY movie.To all you movie critics out there: Movies are meant to entertain, if you don't find a certain movie entertaining, then ALL THAT MEANS is that it wasn't entertaining TO YOU. Just because you don't like a movie doesn't mean it's a bad movie. Thinking it's a bad movie simply because YOU didn't like it is so incredibly pretentious that I think you need to re-evaluate your place in society. I've lived my entire life never listening to any critics; I've watched every movie I ever wanted to see because that's my decision, not theirs. Make your own decisions, watch the movie if you think you'll like it, and don't listen to the critics... EVER.This movie does not disappoint. Of course it's not perfect, no movie is perfect, if you go into a movie theater expecting a perfect movie, you'll always be disappointed, but this movie far exceeded my expectations, and was so much fun I can't wait to see it again. Comic book fans should all really enjoy this movie, I can't tell you how great it was to see what I only ever saw on paper come to life. This is easily one of my favorite movies of all time.

At first, I had little expectations for Nicholas Cage being Ghost Rider and I found that many others agreed. The Ghost Rider Comics are famous and just like Spiderman and X-Men, to make an adaption out of it requires a lot of work. It's not something you can just slap on the big screen; both longtime fans and newcomers have to find the same power that makes Ghost Rider what it is in the comics, on the big screen. So having seeing the film I admit that although it had a few sore spots and kinks, I admire the work put into the movie.The cast did a decent job on pulling the characters together. Kudos to Nicholas Cage for his part as Johny Blaze: not too shaby, he didn't over do it and it was enough to both respect the character and add a little spunk to it. Eva Mendes also did a good job as being the clichéd lost teenage love, although the shirts with the top three buttons unbuttoned was way to obvious. I was satisfied with Peter Fonda's work as Mephistopheles, I just wished he put a little more effort as being the vile demon himself. The rest of the cast only added to the nice effort of a movie that Ghost Rider is. The only faults were the lack of character that the film had. Sure there the main cast carried it, but because the plot was so straight forward, there wasn't room for extra characters to weave and twist the story a little.As said before, the plot was just like an average comic book storyline. A decent interpretation of Ghost Rider and his ideologies, the film should be claimed as a fair success. The soundtrack was great, with a couple of dull scores though. All in all, if you're a dire fan of Ghost Rider it really is a cool action flick to watch and if you're just wanting a quick straightforward ride, then it's a taker too.

I don't know much about Ghost Rider. What I do know is he has a wicked visual: he's a scary mofo in black leather with a burning skull for a face. Please watch this movie for a textbook on how to make that idea boring.I liked most of the other comic book movies that came out: the Spiderman flicks ruled. Blade (the first one at least) ruled. Batman Begins was cool. I don't know what the problem with this movie is. No plot? Crappy dialog? Boring characters? There are some good ideas here, like Johnny not knowing if it is his skill that protects him, or his deal with you-know-who, but these are missed opportunities, far outweighed by boring crap. Actually, the part of the movie BEFORE ghost rider appears is much more interesting than the latter parts. Maybe because they were focusing on the characters and not the demonic effects.Like corn? You'll get a lot of that here. The speech he gives at the end is terrible. Movies based on comics don't have to be like this. Spiderman has a heroic motivation, but he doesn't make a speech about it at the end of his movies.Yes, Ghostrider's cg looks cool. It just needed a cool script to go along with it.

I had doubts going into this movie due to all of the honkies running around these boards not sure if Nicolas Cage could pull it off. Well... he did. He did it very well. Very well done on his part. The entire movie overall was very pleasing, and I was really drawn into it for some reason.If I could of changed anything, I would of developed the character of his dad a bit more. I think that could of used just a TAD bit more attention to make the story feel more real. The ending, although it was pretty sweet and left it open for a sequel, could of been a tid bit longer.Overall. Great movie. I was impressed. And I think when these kids on the boards who are spouting bad reviews about it YET DIDN'T see it, they'll see the same thing.:)

Pretty enjoyable.
Really liked the characters and the story.
Thats pretty much it really.

Review title: I sold my soul to the devil to insure no sequel
Review_body: Ghost Rider has firmly rooted itself as the worst superhero movie since 1990's "Captain America." It may be right there with "Suburban Commando" or "Once a Hero." Etc Etc. It was bad. Real bad. Almost not even funny bad. Cage's character was devoid of character development...he simply learned how to "be" the Ghost Rider, defeating million year old scriptured demons in the course of a weekend, through the power of one scene of self-combustion (not even the banality of montage) and the divine knowledge of Sam Elliot. The screenplay had holes...big holes...craters. It had cheese...lots of that too. Sam Elliot alone was a giant piece of havarti. Eva Mendes? Beautiful?: yes. But her character's significance to the overall story outside of a trite device?...the development of Cage and her's relationship?...the seeds of human interaction...the gist of it, the life, the blood, the crumbly morsel of passion and desire? What's that?, Eva Mendes says while informing her co-worker that she is in love with Johnny Blaze. Love, of course, being the choice word to cover the fact that Mendes character is 30 going on 8. Even the camera work writhed in suckosity, e.g. the extreme stare down close-ups that unveiled themselves in the final battle scene (a scene, I might add, that brings new meaning to the phrase: huh?). So all in all, a crapfest that will make millions. I can only hope that the 900 or so people that have already given this movie a 10 are either impressionable children, the easy-to-please working class (who also raved over last year's film "Sahara") or the mentally impaired. 2/19 Ryan's Reviews

I have to be honest... the only reason I went to see the movie is because my husband wanted to go. That, and after seeing Epic Movie last weekend, I thought Ghost Rider had to be better than THAT at least. But that's another story... So my friend and I sat together at the theater ready to mock it (quietly, of course), but we both ended up being totally engrossed in the movie. Even though I'm a huge Nic Cage fan, I thought "motorcycles?" and "the devil's bounty hunter?" - how dumb! I was surprised to find that it was actually a good story line and funny too! It had it's cheesy moments, but overall was pretty darn great. And there were lots of familiar faces like Sam Elliot, Peter Fonda, Donal Logue and Matt Long that had us saying, "Hey - that's the guy from (fill in the blank)!" I highly recommend seeing it.

I know this comment is one of dozens, and probably will only be scanned by other people who hated the movie, but I must say my peace.This movie was the most predictable piece of trash I've ever seen. Even half of the clichéd one-liners were muttered under my breath a split second before the movie said the exact same line, and I was surprised every time it happened.The idea of "cast a good actor in a terrible role" simply doesn't work in movies. I enjoy Nicolas Cage and Sam Elliott a lot, but their roles were so poorly written that I wanted to leave immediately. If I had been by myself instead of with friends, I would have left.It's bad when you find a movie funny because of how terrible it is. What's even worse is when you start laughing at yourself for paying money to see said filth. Sadly, I fit into that category after seeing "Ghost Rider". Never again...

This movie was god awful. Truly a terrible piece of garbage. I was (un)fortunate enough to have a seat for the "WEST COAST PREMIER" of the film held at Cal. State Long Beach (No Joke). Let's put it this way: There was a reason this film was premiered here and not in Hollywood. It was terrible! The acting was poor to the point of hilarity, the visual effects were mediocre, and the writing was abominable. I am truly ashamed to say that the writer (Mark Steven Johnson) is an alumnus of CSULB. I might have to drop out to be disassociated with him. Wes Bently, who played "Blackheart" in the movie was atrocious. Absolutely the worst acting I've seen in a long time, I mean there were times when I was wondering if his poor delivery and awful composure were intentionally set up for jokes. I tend to think not because the entire audience was laughing at him, not with him. Not with him.Now, the fight scenes. Are you kidding me? Here's my summary of the fights of this movie: First fight with sandman, pretty sweet actually. Some blows on both sides, and sandy died in a fairly cool way. Next fight, on roof top, was totally lame. I mean seriously. Wind dude is like "you can't catch the wind" and then Ghost Rider creates a fire tornado (not as cool as it sounds) and the wind guy is like "oh noes I guess I was wrong" and dies. No fight just... lameness. And is it just me, or did he not even kill the water guy? Granted I left 5 minutes early because it was a bad movie, but I left after he killed hell-boy. That battle, man. GR throws a fire ball, but it was just like a clump of fire. Then he shoots him and he's like dude you cant even hurt me. Then he tries to do his like soul stare thing into the inferno of bad acting Wes and he's like "lol ya rite, I don't have a soul!!1" so GR fails. Then the villain from hell absorbs the souls of 1000 (or was it 5,000?) disgruntled Mexicans or something and GR realizes that now the baddie has A FREAKIN THOUSAND SOULS so he can kill him by looking him in the eyes real romantic like. This is where I left. The only reason I didn't give this movie a 1 is Eva Mendez is hot and was decent in the movie. No comment on Nick Cage, seen him do better and do worse.

Review title: A Good Way To Put It...
Review_body: This movie, isn't the worst thing I have ever seen, but it falls from what I was expecting when I first saw the previews. The visuals were explosive and the story, considering you're packing an extensive comic into a 2 hour movie, was at best presentable. I think the major flaws in this film, were the jackass they got to write the script, and the awful director whom I personally hope in the near future kills himself so that he can no longer ruin any more comic to movie projects. It starts out decent, rides through up until Johnny Blaze FINALLY becomes the Ghost Rider. Then things take a turn for worst, the fight sequences were short and over all unimpressive, and the look of the demons and all that were totally corny (of course no where near as corny as some of the dialogue). It all builds up to a horribly cliché showdown, and a chick flick ending just for a twist. Do yourself a favor, don't go in with high expectations, this movie is sub-average.
